metadata.titleEn: High-resolution tropospheric NO2 VCDs over East Asia POMINO v2.1 (2012-2020)
metadata.description: This data set contains the high-resolution tropospheric nitrogen dioxide vertical column concentration pomino v2.1 data in East Asia from 2012 to 2020. It is a new version of the data after bug fix of v2.0.1, which provides an important data basis for studying the spatial distribution characteristics and temporal change trend of tropospheric nitrogen dioxide in China. Based on the tropospheric nitrogen dioxide slant column concentration provided by KNMI, the pomino tropospheric nitrogen dioxide vertical column concentration is calculated through the tropospheric AMF retrieval algorithm developed by ourselves. The comparison with the ground-based observation data shows that the tropospheric nitrogen dioxide column concentration of pomino can better capture the day-to-day variation trend, and has better correlation with the ground-based observation data. At present, the data has been used for scientific research by many universities and scientific research institutions at home and abroad. In the future, the data set will provide more comprehensive data support for scientific research projects on the Qinghai Tibet Plateau.

background: The retrieval of tropospheric NO2 VCD from OMI is done by dividing the tropospheric slant column density (SCD) by the tropospheric air mass factor (AMF). Current representative OMI products covering China, DOMINO v2 and OMNO2 v2, do not explicitly account for the effect of aerosols on the solar radiation. Since aerosols affect the radiation field in retrieving both clouds and NO2, the net effect on the retrieved NO2 columns is unclear. This aerosol issue is particularly significant over East China due to its high aerosol loadings. In addition, the DOMINO and OMNO2 products also assume Lambertian surface with no dependence of surface reflectance on the geometry of the light path. DOMINO and OMNO2 adopt the vertical profile of NO2 simulated by coarse-resolution global chemical transport models (CTMs), TM4 at 3° long. × 2° lat. for DOMINO v2 and GMI at 2.5° long. × 2° lat. for OMNO2 v2, which are unable to capture the variability of NO2 at smaller scales.
research objective: Here we quantify the influences over China via an improved retrieval process.
methods: We explicitly account for aerosol optical effects (simulated by nested GEOS-Chem at 0.667° long. × 0.5° lat. and constrained by aerosol measurements), surface reflectance anisotropy, and high-resolution vertical profiles of NO2 (simulated by GEOS-Chem). Prior to the NO2 retrieval, we derive the cloud information using consistent ancillary assumptions. We compare our retrieval to the widely used DOMINO v2 product, using MAX-DOAS measurements at three urban/suburban sites in East China as reference and focusing the analysis on the 127 OMI pixels (in 30 days) closest to the MAX-DOAS sites.
dataset: The MAX-DOAS measurements were conducted at three urban/suburban sites in East China, one at the Institute of Atmospheric Physics (IAP), Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) in urban Beijing, one in Xianghe County to the southeast of Beijing, and one in the city of Tai’An. For all sites, the VCD of NO2 is retrieved from the radiation measurements around 477 nm. The total retrieval uncertainty on the tropospheric NO2 column has been estimated at 11% for the Beijing and Xianghe sites (Hendrick et al., 2013) and 14% for the Tai’An site (Irie et al., 2012).
findings: We find that our retrieval reduces the interference of aerosols on the retrieved cloud properties, thus enhancing the number of valid OMI pixels by about 25%. Compared to DOMINO v2, our retrieval better captures the day-to-day variability in MAX-DOAS NO2 data (R2 = 0.96 versus 0.72), due to pixel-specific radiative transfer calculations rather than the use of a look-up table, explicit inclusion of aerosols, and consideration of surface reflectance anisotropy. Our retrieved NO2 columns are 54% of the MAX-DOAS data on average, reflecting the inevitable spatial inconsistency between the two types of measurement, errors in MAX-DOAS data, and uncertainties in our OMI retrieval related to aerosols and vertical profile of NO2.

background: Tropospheric vertical column densities (VCDs) of nitrogen dioxide (NO2) retrieved from the Ozone Monitoring Instrument (OMI) on board the Earth Observing System (EOS) Aura satellite have been widely used to monitor and analyze NOx pollution over China because of their high spatiotemporal coverage. However, NO2 retrieved from OMI and other spaceborne instruments is subject to errors in the conversion process from radiance to VCD, particularly with respect to the calculation of tropospheric air mass factor (AMF) that is used to convert tropospheric slant column density (SCD) to VCD. Most current-generation NO2 algorithms do not explicitly account for the effects of aerosols on NO2 AMFs and on prerequisite cloud parameter retrievals. In polluted situations with high aerosol loadings and more absorbing aerosol types, which often occur over China and many other developing regions, the implicit method can result in considerable biases. Lin et al. (2014b, 2015) established the POMINO NO2 algorithm, which builds on the DOMINO v2 algorithm (for OMI NO2 slant columns and stratospheric correction), but improves upon it through a more sophisticated AMF calculation over China. The CALIOP lidar, carried on the sun synchronous CALIPSO satellite, has been acquiring global aerosol extinction profiles since June 2006.
research objective: This study improves upon the POMINO algorithm by incorporating CALIOP monthly climatology of aerosol vertical extinction profiles to correct for model biases. Here we present a major algorithm update, POMINO v1.1, by constructing a monthly climatological dataset of aerosol extinction profiles, based on level 2 CALIOP/CALIPSO data over 2007–2015, to better constrain the modeled aerosol vertical profiles.
methods: Here we construct a custom monthly climatology of aerosol vertical extinction profiles based on 9 years (2007–2015) worth of CALIOP version 3 level 2 532 nm data. We then use the corrected GEOS-Chem vertical extinction profiles in the retrievals of cloud parameters and NO2. As detailed in Appendix B, we use the daily all-sky version 3 CALIOP level 2 aerosol profile product aerosol at 532 nm from 2007 to 2015 to construct a monthly level 3 climatological dataset of aerosol extinction profiles over China and nearby regions. Our POMINO algorithm focuses on the tropospheric AMF calculation over China and nearby regions, taking the tropospheric SCD from DOMINO v2. POMINO v1.1 (this work) further uses CALIOP data to constrain the shape of the aerosol vertical extinction profile. We run the model at a resolution of 0.3125° long ×0.25° lat before May 2013 and 0.667° long ×0.5° lat afterwards, as determined by the resolution of the driving meteorological fields. We then regrid the finer-resolution model results to 0.667° long ×0.5° lat, to be consistent with the CALIOP data grid.
dataset: CALIOP is a dual-wavelength polarization lidar measuring attenuated backscatter radiation at 532 and 1064 nm since June 2006. We use MAX-DOAS measurements at three suburban or urban sites in East China, including one urban site at the Institute of Atmospheric Physics (IAP) in Beijing, one suburban site in Xianghe County to the south of Beijing, and one urban site in Wuxi City in the Yangtze River Delta (YRD).
findings: The improved NO2 VCDs (in POMINO v1.1) are more consistent with independent ground-based MAX-DOAS observations (R2 =0.80, NMB =−3.4 %, for 162 pixels in 49 days) than POMINO (R2 =0.80, NMB =−9.6 %), DOMINO v2 (R2 =0.68, NMB =−2.1 %), and QA4ECV (R2 =0.75, NMB =−22.0 %) are. Especially on haze days, R2 reaches 0.76 for POMINO v1.1, much higher than that for POMINO (0.68), DOMINO v2 (0.38), and QA4ECV (0.34).

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that accounts for aerosol optical effects when retrieving tropospheric NO2 vertical column densities?
Example.Answer: One example of a data collection method that accounts for aerosol optical effects is the retrieval process that uses aerosol measurements simulated by nested GEOS-Chem and constrained by aerosol data. It explicitly includes aerosol optical effects, surface reflectance anisotropy, and high-resolution vertical profiles of NO2.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that incorporates lidar-based aerosol extinction profiles to improve NO2 retrieval accuracy?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset is the POMINO algorithm, which uses a custom monthly climatology of aerosol vertical extinction profiles based on CALIOP version 3 level 2 data to improve the accuracy of NO2 retrievals.

Example.Question: Could you illustrate an example where ground-based measurements were used to validate satellite data for tropospheric NO2 concentrations?
Example.Answer: An example of using ground-based measurements for validation is the comparison of tropospheric NO2 column retrievals with MAX-DOAS measurements at urban and suburban sites in East China, such as those in Beijing and Xianghe County, to assess the accuracy of satellite data like those from the POMINO algorithm.

Feature Specification.Answer: aerosol optical effects, nested GEOS-Chem simulations, monthly climatological datasets of aerosol extinction profiles using CALIOP data

Definition.Question: What does 'tropospheric air mass factor (AMF)' mean in the context of NO2 vertical column density retrieval?
Definition.Answer: In the context of NO2 vertical column density retrieval, the tropospheric air mass factor (AMF) is used to convert the tropospheric slant column density (SCD) to vertical column density (VCD). It accounts for the effects of aerosols, surface reflectance, and vertical profiles of NO2, which are crucial for accurate retrievals, especially in regions with high aerosol loadings like East China.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'aerosol optical effects' in the context of NO2 data retrieval?
Definition.Answer: Aerosol optical effects refer to the influence of aerosols on the radiation field, which affects the retrieval of both cloud properties and NO2 columns. These effects must be explicitly accounted for to reduce retrieval biases, particularly in regions with high aerosol loads. In NO2 data retrieval, incorporating aerosol optical effects improves the accuracy of the derived NO2 columns.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'high-resolution vertical profiles of NO2' in atmospheric data collection?
Definition.Answer: High-resolution vertical profiles of NO2 are significant in atmospheric data collection as they provide detailed information on the distribution of NO2 at different altitudes. These profiles are crucial for improving the accuracy of NO2 retrievals from satellite data, allowing for better representation of spatial variability, especially in regions like China with complex emission sources and atmospheric conditions.

Comparison.Question: In what ways does the inclusion of aerosol effects in the POMINO algorithm differ from the approach used in DOMINO v2 and OMNO2 v2, and how does this impact the retrieval of NO2 columns?
Comparison.Answer: The POMINO algorithm explicitly considers aerosol optical effects and surface reflectance anisotropy, enhancing the retrieval accuracy of NO2 columns by reducing aerosol interference. DOMINO v2 and OMNO2 v2 do not account for these aerosol effects, leading to potential biases, especially in regions with high aerosol loadings like East China. The improved treatment in POMINO results in better temporal variability capture and higher correlation with ground-based measurements.

Interpretation.Question: How might incorporating aerosol optical effects into tropospheric NO2 VCD retrieval influence the accuracy of data collected over regions with high aerosol loadings?
Interpretation.Answer: Incorporating aerosol optical effects into the retrieval of tropospheric NO2 VCD can significantly enhance data accuracy by reducing interference from aerosols on retrieved cloud properties. This approach better captures day-to-day variability in NO2 data and increases the number of valid satellite observation pixels, especially in regions like East China with high aerosol loadings.

Interpretation.Question: How do variations in spatial resolution of chemical transport models impact the retrieval of NO2 VCDs in densely populated regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Variations in spatial resolution can significantly impact the retrieval of NO2 VCDs by either capturing or failing to capture the variability of NO2 at finer scales. High-resolution models, such as those used in the POMINO algorithm, allow for more accurate representation of NO2 concentration distributions, particularly in densely populated areas, compared to coarser models, which may overlook smaller scale variabilities.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might aerosol optical effects need to be explicitly accounted for in the retrieval of tropospheric NO2 VCD over regions like China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Aerosol optical effects need to be explicitly accounted for because aerosols significantly affect the radiation fields used in retrieving both clouds and NO2. This is particularly pertinent in regions like China where there are high aerosol loadings, which can lead to considerable biases in the retrieved NO2 columns if not properly addressed.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the improvement in accuracy of NO2 VCD retrievals when using higher-resolution models and additional aerosol data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The improvement in accuracy of NO2 VCD retrievals is caused by using higher-resolution models that capture detailed vertical profiles of NO2 and including aerosol data, such as CALIOP monthly climatology of aerosol vertical extinction profiles. This approach reduces the interference of aerosols on cloud properties and enhances the retrieval's consistency with ground-based observations, such as MAX-DOAS measurements.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of developing datasets for tropospheric NO2 vertical column densities specifically for East Asia from 2012 to 2020?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives include providing a foundational dataset for studying the spatial distribution and temporal trends of tropospheric NO2 in the region, addressing errors in previous versions, and enhancing the understanding of NO2 variability in East Asia, particularly in China, by using a high-resolution approach that explicitly accounts for aerosol effects and surface reflectance anisotropy.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to improve retrieval algorithms for NO2 VCDs by incorporating aerosol optical effects and high-resolution vertical profiles?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Improving retrieval algorithms by incorporating aerosol optical effects and high-resolution vertical profiles is crucial because it reduces the interference of aerosols on the retrieved NO2 columns, enhances the accuracy of NO2 data by capturing day-to-day variability more effectively, and addresses biases in existing algorithms that do not fully account for aerosol impacts, particularly in regions with high aerosol loadings like East China.

Goal Orientation.Question: What goals drive the development of advanced algorithms like POMINO that incorporate CALIOP data for NO2 retrievals over China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals include correcting model biases by using aerosol vertical extinction profiles, improving the accuracy of NO2 VCDs, achieving better consistency with ground-based observations, and enhancing the understanding of pollution dynamics over China by using more sophisticated AMF calculations and climatological datasets that reflect the actual aerosol conditions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the vertical profile of NO2 determined for high-resolution retrieval processes in East Asia?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The vertical profile of NO2 is simulated using the GEOS-Chem model, allowing for a high-resolution representation of NO2 that is essential for accurate retrieval over regions with significant spatial variability such as East Asia.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are involved in constructing a climatological dataset of aerosol extinction profiles for the purpose of improving NO2 retrieval algorithms?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The process involves using 9 years of CALIOP version 3 level 2 data to construct a monthly climatology of aerosol vertical extinction profiles. This dataset is then used to correct model biases in the GEOS-Chem vertical profiles, which are integrated into the retrievals of cloud parameters and NO2.

Enablement.Question: What methods have been developed to enhance the accuracy of tropospheric NO2 vertical column density retrieval over high aerosol loading regions like East China?
Enablement.Answer: To enhance accuracy, methods such as accounting for aerosol optical effects using nested GEOS-Chem simulations, considering surface reflectance anisotropy, and using high-resolution vertical profiles of NO2 have been developed. These methods improve the retrieval process by reducing the interference of aerosols and capturing day-to-day variability more effectively.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of CALIOP lidar data enable improved aerosol profile modeling for NO2 retrieval algorithms?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of CALIOP lidar data allows for the construction of a monthly climatological dataset of aerosol extinction profiles, which helps to correct model biases in aerosol vertical profiles. This enhances the accuracy of tropospheric air mass factor calculations and improves NO2 retrieval by providing better constraints on the aerosol vertical extinction profiles.

Enablement.Question: What technological and methodological advancements have facilitated the improvement of NO2 retrieval algorithms in regions with complex atmospheric conditions?
Enablement.Answer: Advancements such as the development of the POMINO algorithm, which incorporates sophisticated AMF calculations and the use of high-resolution model simulations, have facilitated improvements. Additionally, the use of CALIOP lidar data for aerosol extinction profiles and the explicit inclusion of aerosol effects in NO2 retrieval algorithms have played a crucial role in addressing complex atmospheric conditions.

Expectation.Question: What factors could contribute to differences in NO2 measurement consistency between satellite-based retrievals and ground-based observations?
Expectation.Answer: Differences in measurement consistency can arise from spatial inconsistency between satellite and ground-based measurements, errors in ground-based MAX-DOAS data, and uncertainties in satellite retrievals related to aerosols and the vertical profile of NO2. Satellite retrievals may also use different radiative transfer calculations or assumptions about surface reflectance and aerosol effects.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the potential of incorporating CALIOP data for enhancing the accuracy of aerosol vertical extinction profiles in atmospheric research?
Judgmental.Answer: Incorporating CALIOP data significantly enhances the accuracy of aerosol vertical extinction profiles by providing a well-constrained climatological dataset, which helps correct model biases and improves the consistency of NO2 VCDs with ground-based observations, especially on haze days.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the inclusion of aerosol optical effects and surface reflectance anisotropy impacts the retrieval accuracy of NO2 vertical column densities.
Assertion.Answer: The inclusion of aerosol optical effects and surface reflectance anisotropy improves the retrieval accuracy of NO2 vertical column densities by explicitly accounting for these factors in the retrieval process, which reduces the interference on retrieved cloud properties and enhances the number of valid data points. This leads to better capturing of day-to-day variability in NO2 data.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how the integration of CALIOP lidar data improves the accuracy of aerosol vertical extinction profiles used in NO2 retrievals.
Assertion.Answer: The integration of CALIOP lidar data improves the accuracy of aerosol vertical extinction profiles by providing a monthly climatology that corrects for model biases, resulting in more accurate constraints on the modeled aerosol vertical profiles, which in turn enhances the accuracy of NO2 retrievals.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and analyze the challenges faced in the retrieval of NO2 vertical column densities over regions with high aerosol loadings such as East China.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include errors in the conversion process from radiance to VCD, particularly with respect to the calculation of tropospheric air mass factor (AMF). Most algorithms do not explicitly account for the effects of aerosols, which can result in considerable biases in polluted situations with high aerosol loadings. This is significant over East China due to its high aerosol loadings, affecting the accuracy of the retrieved NO2 columns.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate potential datasets that could be utilized to improve the accuracy and resolution of NO2 retrievals in East Asia.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include MAX-DOAS measurements at urban/suburban sites in East China, CALIOP lidar data providing global aerosol extinction profiles, and high-resolution GEOS-Chem simulations. These datasets help in constructing climatological datasets of aerosol extinction profiles, which are crucial for refining the model biases and improving the NO2 vertical column density retrievals.
